metadata.title: Epilepsy
anatomical location body part affected: Cerebral cortex. Depending on the location and type of altered brain activity, the entire body can be affected
description: During a seizure, abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal discharge occurs in the cerebral cortex of the brain. This results in a sudden, transient change in behavior.(1) The diagnosis of epilepsy requires the occurrence of at least one epileptic seizure, but, in practice, epilepsy is most commonly diagnosed after two or more unprovoked seizures.(1)Epilepsy refers to a clinical phenomenon rather than a single disease entity because there are many forms and causes of epilepsy(2)

The International League against Epilepsy (ILAE) has finalized an operational definition that is suitable for clinical use(7) –Epilepsy is present when any of the following conditions is met: -At least two unprovoked (or reflex) seizures occurring more than 24 hours apart -One unprovoked (or reflex) seizure and a probability of further seizures similar to the general recurrence risk (at least 60%) after two unprovoked seizures, occurring over the next 10 years; or -Diagnosis of an epilepsy syndrome –Epilepsy is considered to be resolved for individuals who either had an age-dependent epilepsy syndrome but are now past the applicable age or those who have remained seizure-free  for the last 10 years and off anti-seizure  medicines for at least the last 5 years

Provoked nonreflex (or acute symptomatic) seizures are seizures provoked by factors that temporarily reduce the seizure threshold (e.g., within 7 days of stroke or head trauma or in conjunction with a metabolic derangement)(8)

Epilepsy is considered a common disease, affecting about 50 million persons worldwide; lifetime risk of developing epilepsy is estimated at 3% to age 80 years. The incidence of epilepsy is about 55 per 100,000 population in the United States and Europe, with the highest incidence in infants younger than 1 year and in adults older than 60 years of age(1)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Seizures – either generalized or focal. The ILAE classifies seizures into generalized and focal seizures(2) –Generalized seizures arise within and rapidly engage networks distributed across both cerebral hemispheres and may result from cellular, biochemical, or structural abnormalities that have a widespread distribution(2) -Absence seizures -Typical -Characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness without loss of postural control -Usually accompanied by subtle, bilateral motor signs such as rapid blinking of eyelids or small amplitude, clonic movements of the hands -Associated with a group of genetically determined epilepsies with onset usually in childhood (4–8 years) and the main seizure type in 15–20%  of children with epilepsy -Can occur 100 times per day but child might be unaware of or unable to convey their existence -Atypical -Lapse of consciousness is usually longer and less abrupt in onset -Usually accompanied by more obvious motor signs that might include focal and lateralizing features -Associated with diffuse or multifocal structural abnormalities in the brain and so may accompany other signs of neurologic dysfunction (e.g., intellectual disability) -Less responsive to anticonvulsant therapy than typical absence seizures -Tonic-clonic -Main seizure type in approximately 10% of all persons with epilepsy -Most common seizure type resulting from metabolic derangements -Usually begins abruptly without warning with tonic features (contraction of muscles of expiration and larynx to cause “ictal cry,” cyanosis, contraction of jaw muscles with biting of tongue, increases in heart rate, blood pressure, and pupillary size); then moves into clonic phase (relaxation and unresponsiveness, muscular flaccidity and excessive salivation, bladder or bowel incontinence). Patient often falls to ground and is not immediately responsive. Once responsive, clients complain of headache, fatigue, and muscle aches -Clonic – variant of tonic-clonic -Tonic – variant of tonic-clonic  and can be associated with specific epileptic syndromes -Atonic -Sudden loss of postural muscle tone with brief impaired consciousness -Dangerous due to risk of direct head injury with resulting fall -Associated with known epilepsy syndromes -Myotonic -A sudden and brief muscle contraction that may involve one part of body or the entire body -Often seen as sudden jerking movement when falling asleep -Associated with metabolic disorders, degenerative CNS diseases, and anoxic brain injury -Caused by cortical dysfunction and usually coexist with other forms of generalized seizures but are the predominant feature in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy

Focal seizures – arise from a neuronal network either discretely localized or broadly distributed within one hemisphere(1) –Symptoms vary based on the area of the cortex involved -Motor symptoms -Somatosensory symptoms -Autonomic symptoms -Psychological/emotional symptoms –Individual sometimes experiences an aura (a subjective sensation or motor phenomenon) –There is an interruption of ongoing activity and/or blank staring

Epilepsy syndromes(3) (for detailed information, visit https://www.epilepsy.com/ )  –Infantile spasms (West syndrome) -Most frequently seen at 4–6 months of age -Often due to tuberous sclerosis or perinatal asphyxia –Lennox-Gastaut  syndrome -Most frequently seen at 3–5 years of age -Caused by various conditions that lead to significant brain abnormalities –Childhood absence epilepsy (petit mal epilepsy, pyknolepsy) -Accounts for up to 4% of all childhood cases of epilepsy -Children have blank staring spells (no convulsions) –Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome, impulsive petit mal, myoclonic epilepsy of adolescence, and jerk epilepsy) -Commonly presents during puberty -Myoclonic seizures –Benign rolandic epilepsy (benign partial epilepsy of childhood) -Onset is middle childhood -Seizures usually occur during sleep –Rasmussen's syndrome (Rasmussen's encephalitis) -Childhood onset -Impacts entire hemisphere of the brain with contralateral impact on function –Landau-Kleffner  syndrome -Rare condition; onset is usually at 3–7 years of age -Receptive and expressive language is impacted, and type of seizures observed with this syndrome vary –Temporal lobe epilepsy -Complex partial seizures and simple partial seizures are most frequently observed -Impairment in memory may arise –Frontal lobe epilepsy -Characterized by partial seizures -Negative impact on social interactions due to seizure expression (e.g., screaming or suggestive gestures during seizure) –Reflex epilepsy -Photosensitive epilepsy (seizures due to lighting) -Onset is generally in childhood –Progressive myoclonic epilepsy -Rare -Myoclonic and tonic-clonic  seizures -Child might have muscle rigidity and impaired balance Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Underlying-cause  terminology is divided into genetic, structural-metabolic,  and unknown causes(1)–Genetic-Childhood absence epilepsy-Autosomal dominant nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy-Dravet syndrome (epileptic encephalopathy of childhood characterized by onset in infancy that results in intractableseizures, recurrent status epilepticus, and cognitive impairment)(25)–Structural-metabolic-Cortical malformations-Cortical dysplasias-Metabolic abnormalities–Idiopathic-Epilepsy of infancy with migrating focal seizures-Myoclonic epilepsy in infancy-Benign rolandic epilepsy-Panayiotopoulos syndrome-Benign occipital epilepsy of the Gastaut type

Causes according to age(2)–Neonatal period and early infancy-Hypoxic-ischemic  encephalopathy, trauma, CNS infection, congenital CNS abnormalities, and metabolic disorders–Late infancy and early childhood-Febrile (most common) – simple febrile seizures are not associated with epilepsy but children who have complex febrileseizures have a 2–5% increased risk of developing epilepsy–Childhood – the period during which many well-defined  epilepsy syndromes present-Temporal lobe epilepsy–Adolescence and early adulthood – epilepsies secondary to acquired CNS lesions begin to predominate (head trauma,CNS infections, brain tumors, congenital CNS abnormalities, illicit drug use or alcohol withdrawal)-The more severe the head trauma, the greater the likelihood of developing epilepsy–Older adults-Cerebrovascular disease, trauma, CNS tumors, degenerative diseases–At any age-Metabolic disturbances (electrolyte imbalance, hypo or hyperglycemia, renal failure, hepatic failure)-Endocrine disorders, hematologic disorders, and many other systemic diseases may cause seizures over a broad agerange-Medications and abused substances
pathogenesis: A seizure occurs when there is atypical, synchronous, and excessive firing of neurons, resulting in disruption of the normalcontrol of the CNS(4)

The hallmark of an established seizure is an electrographic spike due to intense near-simultaneous  firing of a large numberof local excitatory neurons. This results in a hypersynchronization of the excitatory bursts across a relatively large corticalregion(2)
Astrocyte uncoupling has been implicated as a cause of mesial temporal lobe epilepsy with sclerosis(11)
risk factors: There is an increased risk of epilepsy after having sustained a traumatic brain injury or a subarachnoid hemorrhage(27)–Mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) – in a large prospective study of over a half a million active duty U.S. Air Forceairmen, mTBI was positively associated with epilepsy/recurrent seizure outcomes, post-concussive  syndrome, and paindisorders(12)–Subarachnoid hemorrhage – incidence of epilepsy at 5 years post subarachnoid hemorrhage was 12% according to a studyconducted in Finland(13)–married

Other risk factors include–tumors–genetic factors–inherited metabolic disorders–Alzheimer’s disease–stroke–subdural hematomas(27)–infection–possibly alcohol consumption-Is associated with increased risk of unprovoked seizures/epilepsy-Long-term  excessive consumption is associated with increased risk of provoked seizures related to withdrawal

Risk factors that have been shown to increase risk of recurrence of seizure(1)–Presence of aura preceding generalized or focal seizure–Presence of specific generalized or focal neurologic deficits (e.g., transient unilateral hemiparesis)–Remote symptomatic etiology (seizure that first occurs 6 months following a traumatic brain injury or stroke)–First seizure onset during waking hours–Family history of seizures or epilepsy in some, but not all, studies
Once two or more seizures have occurred, risk of an additional seizure is well over 50%,closer to 70%,and treatment withmedication is recommended(1)

overall contraindications precautions: Physical therapists treating patients with epilepsy should be appropriately trained to manage the situation should a seizure occur. For seizures in which motor function is impaired (i.e., tonic, clonic, and tonic-clonic  seizures), the individual should be lowered to the ground if he or she is not already there

General guidelines for administering seizure first aid(3) Stay calm Throughout a seizure, protect the patient from harm; eliminate dangerous objects from area Stay with the patient Do not hold down extremities Release restrictive clothing Do not place anything in the patient’s mouth Try to roll the patient onto his or her side If possible, place a pillow under the patient’s head Time the seizure In the rare circumstance that the patient does not begin breathing again post seizure, begin rescue breathing

Most individuals with epilepsy will not need emergency medical care following a seizure. However, in the following circumstances emergency medical help is indicated(3) If the patient has diabetes, hypoglycemia, a brain infection, a head injury, or heat exhaustion If the patient is pregnant If the patient has had some type of poisoning or has a high fever If the patient is not recovering as expected (generally after a short rest the person can resume typical functioning) and/or any concerning symptoms are present
To prevent seizures, therapists treating patients with a history of epilepsy should be aware of any provoking factors, such as certain lighting, hyperventilation, or other aggravating stimuli
Persons with epilepsy should wear medical alert jewelry so that prompt medical treatment can be obtained if a seizure occurs
Persons with poorly controlled epilepsy should not drive. Each state has its own law regarding which persons with a history of seizures are allowed to drive
Avoid machinery or activities in which loss of awareness would cause great danger, such as climbing to high places, biking, and swimming alone
Therapists should obtain parental consent before treating a minor

The prone position (lying face down)has been associated with sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP). Therefore it is suggested that to avoid SUDEP, persons with epilepsy should avoid lying in the prone position(30)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When did the seizures begin? Has the cause of the seizures been identified? When was the last seizure? How frequent are the seizures? What type of seizures does the patient have? For what is the patient presenting to therapy? -Hippocampal atrophy has been found in patients with a long history of drug-resistant  temporal lobe epilepsy(21)

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management An antiepileptic drug (AED) should be in use based on seizure type and epilepsy syndrome. If switching drugs, overlap drugs and gradually withdraw the first drug when the second is effective Refer to epilepsy center for consideration of surgery if seizures are refractory to two AEDs(8) Surgical treatment includes resection, destruction or disconnection of epileptic brain tissue, and neurostimulation(8)  The most common surgical procedure for patients with temporal lobe epilepsy involves resection of the anteromedial temporal lobe or a more limited removal of the underlying hippocampus amygdala(2) For some, surgery can be extremely effective in reducing seizures or even making a patient seizure-free(2) Authors of a Cochrane review of research on surgery for epilepsy identified 177 studies, but only 4 RCTs were included; they noted that the quality of data in relation to the recording of adverse events is very poor(9) Researchers were able to identify prognostic factors associated with a better post-surgical  seizure outcome An abnormal preoperative MRI No use of intracranial monitoring Complete surgical resection Presence of mesial temporal sclerosis Concordance of preoperative MRI and EEG History of febrile seizures Absence of focal cortical dysplasia/malformation of cortical development Presence of tumor Right-sided  resection and presence of unilateral interictal (period between seizures) spikes Consider withdrawal of AED after a minimum 2-year  seizure-free period Other procedures include vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) and deep brain stimulation Authors of a 2015 Cochrane systematic review concluded that VNS was effective and well-tolerated  for the treatment of partial seizures(14) The vagal nerve stimulator is an implantable device similar to a cardiac pacemaker Authors of another meta-analysis  investigating adjunct VNS in studies of patients with Dravet syndrome (there were 68 total patients in the studies) found that VNS resulted in greater than 50% reduction in seizure activity for 55.9% of the patients. Some studies also reported improved overall functioning, reduced occurrence of status epilepticus, and increased levels of alertness(25) Authors of a 2015 systematic review and meta-analysis  found that patients with refractory epileptic seizures would benefit from a surgical treatment approach and are more likely to experience seizurefree  outcomes compared to nonsurgical  management for refractory epileptic seizures(31)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Does the patient feel the medications are effectively controlling the seizures? Many different anticonvulsants are used to treat epilepsy. Factors to be considered are age, sex, presumed spectrum of activity, adverse effect profile, druginteraction  potential, effect of treatment on associated comorbidities, contraindications, dosing constraints, cost and affordability, and individual attitudes.(8)Patients need to work with their doctors to find the medication or combination of medications that will effectively reduce seizure activity Medication prescribed is first based on seizure type but also on side effects and comorbidities(1) Phenytoin (Dilantin, Phenytek) is the most widely used and familiar AED despite having the most problematic side effects (gum hypertrophy, hirsutism, cerebellar ataxia or atrophy, peripheral neuropathy, rare hypersensitivity and hepatitis) Partial seizures  carbamazepine, lamotrigine, levetiracetam, oxcarbazepine, topiramate, gabapentin Refractory focal seizures  lacosamide, pregabalin, zonisamide Authors of a 2016 systematic review have suggested that levetiracetam can be provided as an add-on  therapy treatment and is well  tolerated as an antiepileptic drug(29) Generalized seizures  lamotrigine, topiramate, valproic acid (avoid with women), zonisamide Absence seizures  ethosuximide (pure absence seizures only  not for tonic-clonic  or myotonic), lamotrigine, valproic acid, topiramate Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy  valproic acid (avoid in women), topiramate, lamotrigine, zonisamide, levetiracetam Myoclonic seizures  valproic acid, clonazepam, levetiracetam (avoid lamotrigine) Women of childbearing potential  lamotrigine, topiramate, levetiracetam, oxcarbazepine (avoid valproic acid due to increased risk of teratogenicity) Older adult patients  lamotrigine, gabapentin, levetiracetam, topiramate (avoid polypharmacy, highly protein-bound AEDs, and AEDs with high drugdrug  interactions) Depression  lamotrigine, topiramate  Bipolar disorder  valproic acid, carbamazepine, lamotrigine, topiramate Migraine  valproic acid, topiramate. Consider sex, side-effect profile, and seizure type in choosing Chronic pain  pregabalin, gabapentin Neuropathic pain  carbamazepine, gabapentin, pregabalin The risks associated with antiepileptic medications during pregnancy are of concern to women with epilepsy(1) Rates of major congenital malformations in children of women taking antiepileptic medications are about twice those of the general population. However, the risk to the fetus of seizures is generally thought to be greater than the risk to the fetus of antiepileptic medication, so patients are generally advised to continue taking the medication at the lowest effective dose(1) Researchers who conducted a 2015 systematic review of studies of the experiences and views of children taking medication for seizures found that children and adolescents knowingly and/or unknowingly take risks with their epilepsy and that there are no effective interventions available that improve epilepsy medication adherence in these populations(15)
diagnostic tests completed: Electrolyte, BUN, creatinine, glucose, calcium, magnesium are sometimes assessed
Evidence-based  guidelines to evaluate the appropriateness of initial radiologic examinations for patients with seizures and epilepsy contain the following summary statements(10)
MRI is the imaging test of choice for surgical candidates
Patients with new-onset  seizures should undergo imaging with either CT or MRI, with MRI being the preferred modality
CT is the imaging test of choice in the evaluation of patients presenting with seizures following acute trauma
Use of intravenous contrast with either MRI or CT is useful in the assessment for underlying tumor, infection, inflammatory lesion, or vascular pathology
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether the patient/caregiver feels these treatments have been helpful Researchers who conducted a Cochrane systematic review concluded that yoga treatment was better than no intervention or postural exercises mimicking yoga in the control of seizures but could not come to any conclusions regarding the efficacy of yoga in the treatment of uncontrollable epilepsy due to methodological deficiencies in the explored trials(16) Researchers of a follow-up  study of 48 children with intractable epilepsy receiving ketogenic diets (classical, mediumchain  triglyceride [MCT], and modified Atkins) found that the diets were comparably effective in seizure control and generally welltolerated(17) Three patients became seizure-free  and 35 reported 5090%  reduction in seizures during 2-year  period Authors of a systematic review with 8 studies examining the Mozart effect (listening to 10 minutes of Mozart sonatas to improve brain functioning) on childhood epilepsy reported that the Mozart effect might result in reduced epileptiform discharges or seizures in children with epilepsy. The Mozart effect might have a role as an adjunct to both medical and surgical management of childhood epilepsy; however, no causal relationship has been established between reduced seizure activity and Mozart’s music(24)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for any other condition and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: What triggers have been identified? Seizure triggers include but are not limited to -sleep deprivation and alcohol use and withdrawal(1) -noncompliance with medication regimen(3) -lighting (flashing lights, strobe lights, etc.)(3) -stress -hyperventilation
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms before, during, and after a seizure. Generally, no pain is experienced when the individual is not having seizure activity. The individual is more likely to experience postictal confusion (altered state of consciousness after a seizure), fatigue, sleep, focal neurologic signs, and muscle aches after  a generalized tonic-clonic seizure.(1) If pain is noted, it should be investigated to determine if injury occurred during the seizure
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document if there is any pattern noted to the patient’s seizures -The presence of an aura, a subjective sensation or motor phenomenon that precedes a generalized or focal seizure, favors the diagnosis of epilepsy(1)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document the patient’s overall sleep quality and quantity
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, headache, depression) -Migraine headache is the most common headache in patients with epilepsy(18)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient have any history of respiratory compromise? Any need for supplemental oxygen? Barriers to learning -Up to a quarter of individuals with epilepsy have an intellectual disability and persons with intellectual disabilities have a 1/5 chance of having epilepsy(32) -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has the patient had any surgery or implanted devices, such as a vagus nerve stimulator? Any previous history of head injury?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is patient employed or in school? Many patients have difficulty obtaining or maintaining employment or functioning in school. Federal and state legislation is designed to prevent employers from discriminating against employees with epilepsy.(2) Does seizure activity prevent or complicate participation in occupational, leisure, or physical activity? Is patient fearful of participation in activities?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Are there any noted limitations in function or ADLs? Any use of adaptive or assistive equipment? Inquire about psychosocial issues. Cultural stigma regarding epilepsy continues to exist in some environments(2)
social and occupational history.living environment: Document information about stairs, number of floors in home, and with whom patient lives (e.g., family, caregivers). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? -Management of childhood epilepsy varies depending on living environment -Negative cultural attitudes toward epilepsy cause many women/families to hide an epilepsy diagnosis when entering into marriage negotiations in Pakistan for fear of marriage proposal rejection. The International League against Epilepsy has a goal of creating an accepting environment for women with epilepsy(19)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  Generally, the therapist is not evaluating/ treating a patient for epilepsy itself; rather, the epilepsy is a comorbidity. The therapist is advised to complete a general exam as indicated by the patient’s primary diagnosis. Additionally, therapists should assess for medication adherence and inquire about side effects from seizure medications (including dizziness, nausea, fatigue, and suicidal ideation).(23)Side effects from medications should be documented and reported to the patient’s physician.(23)Therapists should maintain a heightened awareness of the potential for seizures during therapy(23)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document use of assistive and adaptive devices; determine appropriateness. Patient may use a protective helmet
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess the patient’s balance in sit and stance, dynamically and statically
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for any abnormalities and assess safety with tests such as Dynamic Gait Index (DGI)Assess motor function as indicated by the diagnosis/reason for referral
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Complete a general strength assessmentInquire about a young child’s acquisition of gross motor skills; any noted delay? Use Peabody Developmental Motor Scales or other pediatric measure as indicated
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Grossly assess ROM throughout extremities and trunk
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess reflexes for symmetryIs there any impairment in ADLs and self-care?
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Medications used to treat epilepsy generally have side effects, which include drowsiness and confusion. Screen cognition with Mini-Mental  State Exam (MMSE) as indicated. Obtain results of testing done by other disciplines (e.g., psychology, speech-language  pathology) where available –Authors of a systematic review on neuropsychological outcomes after temporal lobe surgery in children with epilepsy found that the majority of study participants remained stable following surgery. There were also participants with increased cognitive deficits, especially with respect to memory, and others who demonstrated improvements, especially for those with lower pre-surgical cognitive abilities(26)Retrieved evidence highlights the need for improvements to quality of methodology and reporting. Appropriately designed prospective multicenter trials should be conducted with adequate follow-up  for long-term outcomes to be measured. Core outcome measures should be agreed upon between centers. This would permit higher quality evidence so that clinicians, young persons, and their families may make better-informed  decisions about whether to proceed with surgery and likely postoperative profile

contraindications precautions: Throughout a seizure, protect the patient from harm; eliminate dangerous objects from area
Do not place anything in the patient’s mouth
Try to roll the patient onto his or her side
If possible, place a pillow under the patient’s head
In the rare circumstance that the patient does not begin breathing again post seizure, begin rescue breathing
other: Patients with epilepsy are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
General guidelines for administering seizure first aid(3)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Therapists generally do not treat epilepsy specifically; however, epilepsy is sometimes a comorbid diagnosis. Patients might have physical impairments related to the underlying cause of epilepsy
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Transient ischemic attack (TIA)(1)  Syncope(1) Migraine(1) Psychogenic nonepileptic spells (pseudoseizures)(1) Sleep disorders(1)
prognosis: Prognosis depends on type of seizure disorder(4)
Seventy to eighty percent of patients with epilepsy will go into remission(5)
Number of seizures within 6 months after first presentation is the most important factor for remission(4)
Life expectancy is shortened in persons with epilepsy(4)

Increased mortality not attributable to other underlying conditions is associated with:(2) –accidents – most deaths are accidental due to impaired consciousness –status epilepticus -Status epilepticus is prolonged, repetitive seizure activity that lasts longer than 20 to 30 minutes, during which time the patient is unconscious; status epilepticus is a medical emergency associated with poor functional outcomes; can result in death. Complications of status epilepticus include hypoxia, respiratory acidosis, and cardiac problems such as stress cardiomyopathy(22) –sudden unexpected death in epileptic patients (SUDEP) – a syndrome that affects young persons and tends to occur at night
Persons with epilepsy are at risk for developing psychiatric problems, including anxiety, depression, and psychosis(2) –Depression occurs in about 20% of patients
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Back to physician as indicated; to specialist epilepsy nurse, pharmacist, OT, speech-language pathologist, social worker, or vocational counselor as indicated; to counselor for self-management  and psychological issues such as anxiety and depression; to support groups as indicated and available
other considerations: The following compounds and interventions are currently under investigation as potential tools to prevent epilepsy or protect against neuronal damage(8) –Other antiepileptic drugs –Dietary treatments -Ketogenic diet(17) –Brain cooling –Antioxidants and free-radical  scavengers –Immunosuppressive treatments and agents targeting brain inflammation –Modulators of glutamatergic transmission –Activators of neurotrophic receptors –Antiapoptotic agents –Brain stimulation –Agents affecting blood-brain  barrier permeability –Transplantation of cells –Suppression of respiratory alkalosis

Various strategies and programs have been developed to improve care of children with epilepsy. There is insufficient evidence to recommend any single program as being more effective than any other(6) –Based on a Cochrane systematic review –Education and counseling programs for children, children and parents, or teenagers and parents were evaluated –No program was shown to have any negative impact –Recommendations include further studies that improve generalizability, evaluate the effectiveness of interventions for subgroups most likely to benefit (e.g., children with newly diagnosed epilepsy, children with learning disabilities), and consider the cost-effectiveness  of the service models

Mental health and social support may be of more importance to the quality of life (QOL) of children aged 8–14  years than control of seizures in children with epilepsy(20)  –Based on a cross-sectional  study conducted in Canada of 480 children aged 8–14 –Child mental health and peer support had direct associations with QOL and parental support had both direct and indirect associations with QOL –Seizure status had only a weak relationship with QOL

The incidence of epilepsy is high among older adults, increasing after the age of 75(2) –Seizures in older adults sometimes have an atypical clinical presentation, making them difficult to recognize -Complex partial and simple partial seizures are the most common and may present as confusion, memory lapses, change in mental status, and staring –Medication options may be limited by altered physiology due to aging and multiple medications for other medical conditions
Authors of a systematic review accessing the Cochrane database system have concluded that current evidence does not support the use of acupuncture treatment for individuals with epilepsy(28)
treatment summary: Proper management and prevention of injury during a seizure is of utmost importance for patients with epilepsy

Epilepsy itself is not generally treated by physical therapists; however, it is common for physical therapists to treat patients who have epilepsy . desired outcomes: Reduced risk of injury during a seizure
Improved knowledge of information about epilepsy, including precautions

maintenance or prevention: There is no way to prevent epilepsy. However, adequate rest, nutrition, and avoidance of triggers may help to reduce seizure activity

To prevent injury, patients should be educated about seizure precautions. Because most accidents occur when patients have impaired consciousness, restrictions may be placed on driving, swimming, taking unsupervised baths, and working at significant heights or with power tools. Restrictions differ for each patient depending on individual features of the seizures, the degree of seizure control, and age
In the United States, restrictions on driving vary with state laws. Other countries may have more permissive or more restrictive laws for driving
When working with children, focus on mental health, peer support, and parental support to improve QOL(20)
